unit_title: Kinematic Calculations: The Equations of Motion
subject: Physics
expanded_description: Master the five kinematic equations that describe uniform accelerated motion. Learn when to use each equation, how to solve multi-step problems, and apply these powerful tools to real-world situations including free fall, projectile motion, and vehicle dynamics.

core_concept.principle: The Five Kinematic Equations connect five motion variables: u (initial velocity), v (final velocity), a (acceleration), s (displacement), t (time)
core_concept.explanation: These equations work ONLY for uniform (constant) acceleration. Each equation contains four of the five variables, allowing you to solve for unknowns when you know three values. The key to success is choosing the equation that contains what you know and what you need.

image.alt: The five kinematic equations displayed with variables labeled
image.caption: Five equations, five variables: u, v, a, s, t | Each equation missing one variable

sections.introduction: These five equations are the foundation of all uniform acceleration problems. Memorize them, understand what each variable represents, and learn which equation to use for different scenarios.

key_concept.definition: Kinematic variables: u = initial velocity, v = final velocity, a = acceleration, s = displacement, t = time
key_concept.context: These equations assume constant (uniform) acceleration. They don't work for non-uniform acceleration or circular motion.

categories.description: Each equation relates four of the five kinematic variables

examples.explanation: Final velocity = initial velocity + acceleration × time | Missing: s (displacement) | Use when you don't know or need displacement
Displacement = initial velocity × time + ½ acceleration × time² | Missing: v (final velocity) | Use when you don't know final velocity
Final velocity squared = initial velocity squared + 2 × acceleration × displacement | Missing: t (time) | Use when you don't know or need time
Displacement = average velocity × time | Missing: a (acceleration) | Use when you don't know acceleration
Displacement = final velocity × time - ½ acceleration × time² | Missing: u (initial velocity) | Less commonly used

categories.description: Understanding what each symbol means and its standard SI unit

examples.explanation: Velocity at the start, measured in m/s. 'From rest' means u = 0.
Velocity at the end, measured in m/s. 'Stops' means v = 0.
Rate of velocity change, measured in m/s². Positive = speeding up forward, negative = slowing down.
Change in position, measured in m. Can be positive or negative.
Time interval, measured in seconds (s). Always positive. Common to all kinematic equations.

sections.introduction: The most important skill in kinematics is selecting which equation to use. This depends on what information you have and what you're trying to find.

key_concept.definition: Identify three known variables → Find equation containing those three plus the unknown → Solve
key_concept.context: Each equation is missing one variable. If you don't know or need that missing variable, that's your equation!

process_flow.description: Identify what you're given and what you need to find
Translate words into numbers. 'From rest' = u = 0, 'stops' = v = 0
process_flow.result: Example: u = 10 m/s, a = 2 m/s², t = 5 s, v = ?, s = ?

process_flow.process: Identify which variable you don't need
process_flow.description: Which of the five variables isn't mentioned and isn't needed?
process_flow.result: Example: Don't need s → Use v = u + at

process_flow.description: Choose the equation missing the unneeded variable
Plug in known values, solve for unknown
process_flow.result: Show work, include units in final answer

process_flow.description: Does your answer make physical sense?

categories.type: Quick Reference: Which Equation to Use
categories.description: Based on what variable you're missing

examples.explanation: Use v = u + at
Use s = ut + ½at²
Use v² = u² + 2as
Use s = ½(u + v)t
Use s = vt - ½at²

sections.introduction: Average velocity is a crucial concept in kinematics. For uniform acceleration, it's simply the average of initial and final velocities.

key_concept.definition: For uniform acceleration: average velocity = ½(u + v)
key_concept.context: This only works for constant acceleration! Equals displacement/time.

principles.application: Quick way to find average when you know start and end velocities
principles.example: Accelerates from 10 m/s to 30 m/s: v_avg = ½(10 + 30) = 20 m/s

principles.statement: s = v_avg × t = ½(u + v) × t
principles.application: This is Equation 4! Useful when acceleration isn't known
principles.example: From 5 m/s to 15 m/s over 10 s: s = ½(5 + 15) × 10 = 100 m

sections.introduction: Many problems have special initial conditions like 'starting from rest' or 'dropped'. Recognizing these simplifies equations dramatically.

key_concept.definition: From rest: u = 0 | Dropped: u = 0 | Comes to rest: v = 0
key_concept.context: These special conditions eliminate terms and simplify calculations.

categories.description: Object starts with zero velocity - very common scenario

examples.process: v = u + at becomes v = at
examples.explanation: Final velocity = acceleration × time only

examples.process: s = ut + ½at² becomes s = ½at²
examples.explanation: Displacement = ½ acceleration × time². Example: Object accelerates from rest at 3 m/s² for 8 s: s = ½(3)(64) = 96 m
Final velocity squared = 2 × acceleration × displacement

categories.description: Object ends with zero velocity - typical braking scenario

examples.process: v = u + at becomes 0 = u + at
examples.explanation: Time to stop: t = -u/a. Car at 15 m/s decelerating at -2 m/s²: t = -15/(-2) = 7.5 s
Stopping distance: s = -u²/(2a). Car at 20 m/s brakes at -5 m/s²: s = -(400)/(-10) = 40 m

sections.introduction: Free fall is uniform acceleration with a = g ≈ 10 m/s² downward. All kinematic equations apply with acceleration = gravity.

key_concept.definition: Free fall: a = g = 10 m/s² (taking downward as positive) | All kinematic equations apply
key_concept.context: Objects in free fall accelerate downward at constant rate, ignoring air resistance.

principles.statement: Dropped means released from rest: u = 0, a = g
principles.application: Use 'from rest' simplified equations with a = 10 m/s²
principles.example: Stone dropped: After 3 s, v = gt = 10 × 3 = 30 m/s downward

principles.statement: Initial velocity is downward (same direction as gravity)
principles.application: Both u and a work together to increase downward speed
principles.example: Thrown down at 5 m/s: After 2 s, v = u + at = 5 + 10(2) = 25 m/s

principles.statement: Initial velocity upward, gravity opposes motion (slows it down)
principles.application: Object slows, stops at peak (v = 0), then falls back
principles.example: Thrown up at 20 m/s: Height = v²/(2g) = 400/(20) = 20 m. Time to return = 2u/g = 40/10 = 4 s (up 2s, down 2s)

categories.description: Typical free fall problem types

examples.explanation: s = ½gt²: Fall 45 m: 45 = ½(10)t² → t² = 9 → t = 3 s
v = gt (if dropped): After 3 s, v = 10 × 3 = 30 m/s
v² = u² - 2gs with v = 0: s = u²/(2g). Thrown at 25 m/s: s = 625/20 = 31.25 m

examples.process: Time to return to starting point
examples.explanation: Time up = Time down. Total = 2u/g. Thrown at 25 m/s: t = 50/10 = 5 s

sections.introduction: Finding acceleration when other quantities are known. The equation choice depends on what information you have.

key_concept.definition: Acceleration = rate of velocity change = (v - u)/t OR from v² = u² + 2as when time unknown
key_concept.context: Positive acceleration with positive velocity = speeding up. Negative acceleration = slowing down (deceleration).

categories.description: When you know initial velocity, final velocity, and time

examples.explanation: Car: 10 m/s to 30 m/s in 5 s: a = (30 - 10)/5 = 4 m/s²
From 4 m/s to 8 m/s in 8 s: a = (8 - 4)/8 = 0.5 m/s²

categories.description: When you know velocities and displacement but not time
When starting from rest with known displacement and time

examples.explanation: From rest, 72 m in 6 s: a = 2(72)/(36) = 4 m/s²

sections.introduction: Finding how long motion takes - time to stop, to reach a speed, or to travel a distance.

key_concept.definition: Time from t = (v - u)/a OR from displacement equations
key_concept.context: Choose simplest method based on available information.

categories.description: When you know velocities and acceleration

examples.explanation: 15 m/s decelerating at -2 m/s² to stop: t = (0 - 15)/(-2) = 7.5 s

categories.description: Finding duration over known distance

examples.explanation: Travels 100 m from 10 m/s to 30 m/s: t = 200/(40) = 5 s

sections.introduction: Finding how far an object travels. Multiple equation options depending on known variables.

key_concept.definition: Four equations can give displacement - choose based on knowns
key_concept.context: s = ½(u + v)t is often easiest when you know both velocities.

categories.description: When both velocities and time are known

examples.explanation: Braking from 20 m/s to 0 in 4 s: s = ½(20 + 0)(4) = 40 m

categories.description: When you know u, a, t but not v

examples.explanation: Start at 10 m/s, a = 2 m/s², t = 5 s: s = 50 + ½(2)(25) = 75 m

categories.description: When velocities and acceleration known but not time
Simplified when u = 0

examples.explanation: From rest at 3 m/s² for 8 s: s = ½(3)(64) = 96 m

sections.introduction: Real scenarios often involve multiple motion phases. Break into segments, solve each, then combine.

key_concept.definition: Break complex motion into segments | Solve each separately | Combine results
key_concept.context: Final velocity of one phase becomes initial velocity of next phase.

process_flow.description: Final velocity of phase 1 = initial velocity of phase 2
Apply appropriate kinematic equation to each
process_flow.result: Find all unknowns for each segment

process_flow.description: Total displacement = sum of all phases

sections.introduction: Recognizing and avoiding predictable errors strengthens problem-solving skills.

categories.description: Using equation that doesn't contain your variables

examples.process: Error: Using v = u + at when time unknown
examples.explanation: If time isn't given, use v² = u² + 2as instead

examples.process: Fix: Identify missing variable → use equation without it
examples.explanation: Which variable do you NOT need? That tells you which equation.

categories.description: Mishandling positive/negative for velocity and acceleration

examples.explanation: If moving forward and slowing, acceleration is NEGATIVE
Same sign (v and a) = speeding up. Opposite signs = slowing down

categories.description: Mixing units without converting

examples.process: Error: Using 72 km/h with a = 2 m/s²
examples.explanation: Convert first! 72 km/h = 20 m/s

examples.process: Fix: Convert to SI units BEFORE calculating
examples.explanation: All values must be in compatible units

categories.description: Not recognizing u = 0 or v = 0 simplifications

examples.process: Error: Using full equation when 'from rest'
examples.explanation: If u = 0, equations simplify dramatically

examples.process: Key phrases: 'from rest' = u = 0, 'stops' = v = 0, 'dropped' = u = 0
examples.explanation: These give you free information

categories.description: Calculation mistakes with negatives and squares

examples.explanation: WRONG! Must square first: 225 - 25 = 200

examples.process: Fix: Write each step clearly, check reasonableness
examples.explanation: Does your answer make physical sense?

summary: The five kinematic equations describe uniform accelerated motion: (1) v = u + at, (2) s = ut + ½at², (3) v² = u² + 2as, (4) s = ½(u + v)t, (5) s = vt - ½at². Each equation contains four of five variables (u, v, a, s, t). To solve problems: identify three known variables, determine which you don't need, select the equation missing that variable. Special conditions simplify: 'from rest' means u = 0, 'stops' means v = 0. For free fall, use a = g ≈ 10 m/s². Average velocity for uniform acceleration = ½(u + v). Always check units, signs, and physical reasonableness of answers.
learning_objectives: Memorize and understand all five kinematic equations
Identify which equation to use based on known/unknown variables
Solve for any kinematic variable given three others
Apply equations to free fall problems
Calculate average velocity for uniformly accelerated motion
Recognize special conditions (from rest, comes to rest)
prerequisites: Understanding of velocity and acceleration concepts
Algebra skills: rearranging equations, solving for variables
Working with squared terms and square roots
Understanding positive and negative in motion
